this data is available. Reference and current policies' are C6 and C7 scenario categories and '2C and
1.5C' are C1, C2 and C3 scenario categories. Each model may have submitted
A systemic view of technological innovation processes
The innovation process, which consists of a set of sequential phases (Section 16.2.1), is often simplified
to a linear process. Yet, it is now well understood that it is also characterised by numerous kinds of
interactions and feedbacks between the domains
of knowledge generation, knowledge translation and
. Furthermore, it is not just invention that
leads to technological change but the cumulative contribution of incremental innovations over time can
. Innovations can come not just from formal R&D but
such as production engineers and the shop floor
This section reviews the literature focusing on innovation as a systemic process. Thi
view enriches the understanding of innovation as presented in section 16.2; it conceptualizes innovation
as the result of actions by, and interactions among, a large set of actors, whose activities are shaped by,
which they operate and the user group with which they are engaging. This
section aligns with the discussion of socio
Supplementary Material in Chapter 5, and Cross
Frameworks for analysing technological innovation processes
The resulting overarching framework that is commonly used in the innovation scholarship and even
policy analyses is termed as “innovation system”, where the key constituents of the systems are
their interactions, and the institutional landscape, including formal rules, such as laws, and informal
restraints, such as culture and codes of conduct, that govern the behaviour of the actors
One application of this framework is that of
importance of national and regional relationships for determining the technological and industrial
capabilities and development of a country
highlight the role of institutions that determine the innovative
performance of national firms as way to understand differences across countries, while Lundvall
focuses on the “elements and relationships which interact in the production, diffusion and use of new,
mically useful, knowledge”, i.e., notions of interactive learning, in which user
or set of technologies (more narrowly or
broadly defined in different cases) as the unit of analysis and focus on explaining what accelerates or
hinders their development and diffusion. Carlsson and Stankiewicz
system as “a dynamic network of agents interacting in a specific economic/ industrial area under a
particular institutional infrastructure and involved in the generation, diffusion, and utilisation of
More recent work takes a “functional approach” to TIS
, which was later expanded with explanations of how
some of the sectoral, geographical and
ions intersect with technology innovation systems
